Title: Load Related Documents
DescriptionLines: **Related documents can be loaded** to the Session from the database when loading the document that references them.
Retrieving a document along with its related documents will occur in a single remote call to the server when using **Include()**.
Using 'Include()' reduces the number of network round trips when working with complex data.

Walkthroughs.Title: Load a document - Include related documents
DescriptionLines: * Use `Include()`to instruct the server to send the related document to the client when loading the primary document.
The document whose ID is specified in the 'Supplier' field of document 'products/34-A' will be sent to the Session upon the Load() command in the following line.
* Now `Load()` the primary document ('products/34-A') from the database.
* _The primary document is loaded_ to the session.
* _The related document is sent_ to the session (not loaded).
* _Both docs are added_ to the Session's internal entities map for tracking changes that will be made to these documents.
* Variable 'product' will hold the 'products/34-A' document entity.
* Note:
* In order to work and modify the related document you still need to make a separate `Load()` call.
This load call will Not go to the server, the document will be retrieved directly from Session (see next step).
* Multiple Include() calls can be made to fetch more than one related document.
* Include is Not recursive, it cannot be used to include documents that are referenced by the included documents.

Walkthroughs.Title: Load the related document
DescriptionLines: * Call `Load()` on the related document (product.Supplier) in order to access it.
* No trip to the server is made, as the related document is retrieved directly from the Session.
* variable 'supplier' will hold the related document entity.

Walkthroughs.Title: Edit document and related document
DescriptionLines: * Edit the primary 'product' document and the related 'supplier' document.
* Both documents are tracked by the Session.
These changes will be persisted to the database upon the next SaveChanges() call.

Walkthroughs.Title: Save the changes
DescriptionLines: * Call `SaveChanges()` to save modifications.
* Changes made to both the primary document and the related document will be saved to the database.
